previousUpdates.title: Regulatory perspective and priorities for 2025
previousUpdates.summary: Speech by Lucy Castledine, director of consumer investments, at the Personal Investment Management   Financial Advice Association (PIMFA) Compliance Conference 2025. Speaker: Lucy Castledine, director, consumer investmentsEvent: PIMFA Compliance Conference 2025Delivered: 25 September 2025Note: this is the speech as drafted and may differ from the delivered version.Reading time: 18 minutesKey messages:We want to challenge ourselves to be a smarter regulator and engage with you so we can raise standards together.Input into our proposals on targeted support and simplified advice – these will define the future for decades to come. Firms should continue to challenge themselves on Consumer Duty and how best to make sure clients have good outcomes.When firms see illegal content online, and have challenges reporting this content to tech platforms, let us know.

previousUpdates.title: Beware of high-risk investments from unregulated firms
previousUpdates.summary: We are concerned people are being encouraged to invest in high-risk schemes offered by unregulated firms without appreciating the risks involved. Many of the firms offering these products don’t need to be authorised by the FCA, as they rely on exemptions in the law that take them out of our remit.If a firm offering an investment is not regulated by the FCA there are generally far fewer protections. For example, you are unlikely to be able to take complaints to the Financial Ombudsman Service and you’re unlikely to be able to make a claim through the Financial Services Compensation Scheme. That may make it much harder to get your money back if something goes wrong.Some of the particularly risky products we’ve seen have been unlisted loan notes or mini-bonds.Unlisted loan notes or mini-bonds come in several forms and are often used to finance property developments. This involves an investor lending money, often via a third-party firm, to fund property developments. While all investments

previousUpdates.title: ESMA provides updated instructions for weekly commodity derivative position reporting
previousUpdates.summary: ESMA provides updated instructions for weekly commodity derivative position reporting 25 September 2025   Trading  The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has published updated reporting instructions and XML schema (version 1.2.0) for the weekly reporting of commodity derivatives positions under the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II (MiFID II), reflecting the changes from the latest review.  Beyond the changes directly originating from MiFID II – such as the requirement to publish two weekly reports and the exclusion of (spot) emission allowances from position reporting – the updated XML schema and reporting instructions also include other amendments to ITS 4, like the harmonisation of reporting units for energy derivatives. The adjustments are based on ESMA’s Final Report submitted to the European Commission in December 2024, which is currently pending adoption. ESMA has opted for this approach to ensure a consistent reporting framework and minimise the need f

previousUpdates.title: Economic Crime Supervision Handbook
previousUpdates.summary: The aim of the EC-S handbook is to give you clear and comprehensive guidance on how to undertake your role within EC-S. It will help you understand the legislation, how our policies work and how they should be applied. It will also explain how to apply the sanctions framework and the powers available for you to use under the Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017 (MLR 2017). Additionally, it may be used by external customers to understand how sanctions are applied.

previousUpdates.title: Tax-free pension lump sums and cancellation rights
previousUpdates.summary: On 25 September 2025, HMRC published newsletter 173 which explains how:tax legislation applies to tax free lump sums andthe tax implications when lump sums are returned to pensionsTo support firms' understanding of that statement, we are providing an explanation of how our existing rules on cancellation rights operate in these scenarios.Under our rules, consumers have the right to cancel certain contracts, typically within 30 days of entering the contract, if they change their mind.However, the right to cancel does not arise in all circumstances. A consumer accessing tax-free cash in itself does not trigger cancellation rights under our rules.Our rules do not exempt firms from HMRC requirements. This means firms should be mindful how they structure their contracts in light of the interaction between HMRC requirements and ours.FCA rules: the right to cancelOur rules, specifically COBS 15.2, ensure that a right to cancel applies when a consumer enters certain specified contracts. In the

artifacts.narrative:
Why This Week Matters
The team tracked 1 significant regulatory developments this week, led by HM Government (1). We observed 1 high-impact items requiring rapid assessment.

The Big Picture
Regulators remain focused on risk management, operational resilience, and consumer protections. Cross-market expectations are converging around more prescriptive controls.

What Changed Since Last Week
The volume of high-impact items shifted modestly, with notable increases in enforcement notices and implementation guidance updates.

Key Storylines
• Compliance obligations related to resilience testing are gathering pace.
• Market conduct authorities emphasised consumer outcomes and disclosure standards.
• Enforcement teams escalated investigations with new fines announced across banking and securities.

Looking Ahead
Expect further clarity on implementation deadlines next week as authorities finalise consultation responses and signal additional enforcement sweeps.
artifacts.onePager:
**Executive Summary**
This week we tracked 1 regulatory updates with 1 high-impact items requiring rapid review.
**Critical Actions Required**
- Validate internal readiness for recently announced resilience expectations.
- Brief senior stakeholders on enforcement trends emerging in capital markets.
- Confirm programme owners for new consultation responses.

**Key Regulatory Developments**
- Operational resilience bulletins from key authorities.
- Enforcement actions referencing consumer duty failings.
- Guidance clarifying cross-border reporting.

**Business Implications**
Firms should stress-test incident response plans and review customer communications to ensure alignment with evolving expectations.

**Recommended Next Steps**
Prioritise stakeholder briefings, track outstanding consultations, and calibrate monitoring for additional enforcement triggers.
artifacts.teamBriefing:
Discussion Points:
- Review the 1 significant updates and assign owners.
- Assess overlap between enforcement actions and upcoming deadlines.

Questions to Investigate:
- Which controls address the highlighted resilience themes?
- Do consumer protections updates require policy adjustments?

Resource Requirements:
- Coordination between compliance monitoring and operational risk.
- Communications support for stakeholder briefings.

Response Timeline:
- Complete impact triage within two working days.
- Prepare briefing materials for the next governance forum.
